message: I could do: pip freeze | cut -d= -f1 > to-delete.txt && pip uninstal to-delete.txt
Does anyone else ever need to flush and recreate a virtualenv (without removing it directly as I have scripts in the bin folder)?
why bother deleting packages?

I have various git branches where I play with different extensions but they all end up in the virtualenv and don't go away when I switch back to master.  I could do with a way of flushing the virtualenv so I can recreate it from requirements.txt
They dont really matter if they're not imported, and if you're properly versioning packages you wont have conflicts

I've ran into this several times and its easy to do. Make sure your virtualenv dirs are not versioned and just wipe them out; rm -rf bin lib include src and then init your project again; cd ..; mkvirutal env proj; workon proj; pip install -r requirements.txt. Something like that.
@zeeg This is usually after Hudson tells me the build is failing from a missing dependency.
@derrickpetzold That works but I don't want to throw away my bin folder within the virtualenv
@zeeg Sometimes I do need to add something to requirements.txt but it's not always easy to spot it from the long list from pip freeze.
Alternatively you could achieve something similar using virtualenv-wrapper and a git post-checkout hook that would run `workon myproj_branchname; pip install -r requirements.txt`
..er that should have been virtualenvwrapper http://www.doughellmann.com/projects/virtualenvwrapper/
If you're not averse to having multiple virtualenvs (one for each branch presumably) you might check out tox: http://codespeak.net/tox/
See https://convore.com/virtualenvwrapper/speeding-up-virtualenv-creation/ for more details
This is why your build server should be starting from scratch with --ignore-site-packages each time ;-)
s/ignore/no
If you don't mind running a branch of pip, you can get a potentially big speedup installing dependencies if you use a download cache.
I reinstall fresh each time. You can run a local chishop server to avoid redownloading.

@unbracketed That's a good idea.  Having a separate virtualenv per git branch is the most conceptually clean way of handling it, and using git-hooks would work well.  I'd still like a good way of flushing and re-installing a virtualenv though.
How about virtualenv --clear . (There is a dot at the end)
@madhavbnk probably worth explaining what that dot equates to (venv path)
dot over there refers to the current directory
